doc.title: Shanxi Fen Wine (A)
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Start of PL cleanup still better visibility among peersStart of PL cleanup still better visibility among peers_2025-08-29

passages.text: Reiterate Rating: BUY | PO: 230.60 CNY | Price: 197.61 CNY

Fen Wine's revenue/NPAT was \(+5.4\% / + 1.1\%\) in 1H25, or \(+0.4\% / - 13.5\%\) in 2Q25.2Q missed VA consensus (revenue/NPAT \(+5\% / + 4\%\) ). We cut 2025/26E EPS \(8\% /7\%\) and lower PO \(4\%\) from RMB240.6 to RMB230.6 (as we roll over our valuation anchor from 2025 to 2026, a year of perceived normalized earnings, and apply a target P/E of 20x from 22.5x, to reflect the current industry down- cycle). Nevertheless, we observe that the market appears to welcome weak results of baijiu companies recently, as the start of P&L cleanup could help to address the previous over- earning issues, and things start to go from bad to less bad, given easing baijiu bans and a lower base. We reiterate our Buy rating as we view Fen Wine as a better name among peers. 1) Amid the recent risk- on rally and laggard trades of China baijiu, Fen Wine historically has enjoyed a higher beta among China's top baijiu companies. 2) Fen Wine also enjoys easier comps in 2H25. P&L cleanup from 2Q also bodes well for the future recovery. 3) In terms of fundamentals, Fen Wine also has better visibility than most large- cap baijiu peers with plenty of market share gain opportunities, as a result of rising brand momentum, its value- for- money positioning in a weak economy and room for nationwide expansion.

Revenue/NPAT was \(+0.4\% / - 13.5\%\) in 2Q25. By segment, mid- to high- end/low- end (97%/3% of sales) were \(+0.6\% / - 3.5\%\) YoY in 2Q25. By channel, wholesale/e- commerce & direct sales (95%/5%) were \(+0.3\% / - 66.9\%\) in 2Q25. Advance payment was \(+4\%\) YoY/+3% QoQ in 2Q25, a positive surprise. Channel inventory is estimated to be \(>3\) months in Shanxi (its home market) and close to 3 months outside Shanxi. Sales outside of Shanxi were \(+4\%\) YoY while Shanxi was \(- 5\%\) in 2Q. GPM was \(- 577\) bp to 49.6%, on higher channel support and an unfavorable mix shift to lower- end Bofen and Lao Baifen from high- end Qinghua. S&D/sales was \(- 2\) bp to 11.5% while G&A/sales was \(+21\) bp to 4.9%. As a result, OP was \(- 13.3\%\) with OPM \(- 543\) p to 34.3%. NPAT was \(- 13.5\%\) YoY, with NPM \(- 403\) bp to 25.0%.

Spirits, Wines & Ciders

Shanxi Fen Wine is China's largest light aroma baijiu producer and the third largest baijiu company by revenue. It produces and sells light aroma baijiu products under the brand clusters "Fen Wine", "Zhuyeqing" and "Xinghuacun". Fen Wine accounts for c.90% of its revenue, with Bofen, Laobafen, Banama, and Qinghua as the four key brands. It was listed Shanghai Stock Exchange in 1994.

We have a Buy rating on Fen Wine. Fen Wine has consistently enjoyed best- of- breed growth among large- cap baijiu names. Its valuation has also become more reasonable in recent years. We think it is well positioned to weather the storm with plenty of EPS buffers.

We trim 2025E/26E EPS by 8%/7% and lower our PO by 4% to RMB20.6. Our PO is based on a 50/50 blend of P/E (RMB216.9) and DCF (RMB244.2). For P/E, we apply a 20x 2026E P/E (roll over from 2025E to 2026E, a year of perceived normalized earnings, and apply 20x P/E vs 22.5x previously), about 0.8x standard deviation below its historical average multiple to reflect the industry downcycle and economic uncertainty. Our DCF value assumes 12.4% WACC, 1.1 beta and 3% terminal growth (unchanged).

Our PO of RMB230.6 is based on a 50/50 blend of P/E (RMB216.9) and DCF (RMB242.2). For P/E, we apply a 20x 2026E P/E, about 0.8x standard deviation below its historical average multiple to reflect economic uncertainty. Our DCF value assumes 12.4% WACC, 1.1 beta and 3% terminal growth.
Upside risks: (1) Surprise policy stimulus, (2) strong demand recovery, (3) rapid market share gain by Fen Wine, and (4) stabilization of management.
Downside risks: (1) Macro downturn and demand contraction, (2) regulatory changes, (3) intensifying competition, (4) continued management upheaval, and (5) food safety issues.
